values.value: Air entry suction (s_ae): Suction value at the intersection between the asymptote and the horizontal line S_e=1, reflecting maximum pore size in soil (units: kPa, range: >0 kPa, derived from Young–Laplace equation: r = 2T cosθ/s, where T=0.072 N/m, θ=0°).

3.1 An equivalent form of VGM.text: The suction value s_ae at the intersection of the asymptote and the line Ŝ_e = 1 can be solved from Eq. (9): [...] which is commonly denoted as air entry suction [13]. Since the value of mn in VGM represents the slope of the asymptote, let us introduce a simple mathematic transformation (β > 0 and K > 0) [...] Air entry suction s_ae is the suction value at the intersection between the asymptote and the horizontal line S_e=1, reflecting the maximum pore size in soil.
3.1 An equivalent form of VGM.relevance: Direct definition of s_ae with physical meaning tied to pore size distribution and capillary law (Young–Laplace equation).

3.2 Assessment of the model parameter.text: Air entry suction s_ae is the suction value at the intersection between the asymptote and the horizontal line S_e=1, reflecting the maximum pore size in soil.
3.2 Assessment of the model parameter.relevance: Explicit physical interpretation of s_ae as a function of pore size.

values.value: Slope of capillary asymptote (K_c): Pore size spectrum number (units: dimensionless, range: >0, derived from log–log linearization of capillary water drainage). Lower K_c indicates more dispersed pore radius distribution.

3.3 Modeling the capillary, adsorption,.text: K_c is the slope of the linear segment for capillary water and represents the pore size spectrum number: the lower the K_c, the more dispersed the pore radius is [55].
3.3 Modeling the capillary, adsorption,.relevance: Direct definition of K_c with physical meaning tied to pore size distribution.

3.4 Parameter calibration method.text: The capillary asymptotes [...] are determined using simple linear regression; K_c is the slope of the capillary asymptote.
3.4 Parameter calibration method.relevance: Empirical validation of K_c as a slope parameter in log–log space.

values.value: Adsorption capacity (w₀ᵃ): Maximum gravimetric water content held via adsorption forces (units: %, range: 0 < w₀ᵃ < w_max, governed by soil specific surface area and mineralogy, e.g., clay content).

Abstract.text: The model parameters possess an unambiguous physical meaning. [...] This study also analyzed the influence of [...] clay content on the [...] adsorption components of the water retention curve.
Abstract.relevance: Highlights adsorption capacity as a physically meaningful parameter linked to clay mineralogy.

3.3 Modeling the capillary, adsorption,.text: w₀ᵃ is defined as 'adsorption capacity' following Lu [13], representing the maximum amount of water that can be held in soil via adsorption force.
3.3 Modeling the capillary, adsorption,.relevance: Explicit definition of w₀ᵃ with physical basis in adsorption mechanisms.

4.3 Water retention data from the litera.text: The adsorption capacity increases significantly with increasing clay content because clay has a much larger specific surface area than the granular components.
4.3 Water retention data from the litera.relevance: Empirical link between w₀ᵃ and specific surface area/mineralogy.

values.value: Adsorption strength (K_a): Slope of the linear adsorption segment in log–log plot (units: dimensionless, range: >0, derived from Freundlich isotherm or van der Waals force decay with suction).

3.3 Modeling the capillary, adsorption,.text: K_a is the slope of the linear segment controlling the desorption rate, referred to as 'adsorption strength' according to Lu [13].
3.3 Modeling the capillary, adsorption,.relevance: Direct definition of K_a as a physically interpretable slope parameter.

1 Introduction.text: Revil and Lu [17] advanced a continuous adsorption equation based on the Freundlich isotherm [31] to replace the constant residual water content in VGM.
1 Introduction.relevance: Theoretical basis for K_a in adsorption isotherms (Freundlich).

values.value: Threshold suction for adsorption (sᵃ): Onset suction for adsorption water desorption (units: kPa, range: >0, marks lower bound of adsorption regime where van der Waals forces dominate).

3.3 Modeling the capillary, adsorption,.text: sᵃ is the threshold value of suction denoting the onset of desorption process of adsorption water and the lower bound of the adsorption regime [13, 54].
3.3 Modeling the capillary, adsorption,.relevance: Explicit definition of sᵃ as a physically meaningful threshold.

3.4 Parameter calibration method.text: The adsorption asymptotes [...] are determined using simple linear regression; sᵃ is the suction at the intersection of the adsorption asymptote and S_e=1.
3.4 Parameter calibration method.relevance: Empirical method to extract sᵃ from SWRC data.

values.value: Transition zone sharpness (β): Parameter controlling the size of the transition zone between capillary and adsorption regimes (units: dimensionless, range: β > 0, default β=1 for original VGM equivalence).

3.2 Assessment of the model parameter.text: β is a parameter that only affects the sharpness and size of the transition zone. For the extreme case of β→0, the transition zone will degrade into a point. [...] For the aim of simplicity, it is sufficient to assume β=1, which is consistent with the original VGM (i.e., m+1/n=1).
3.2 Assessment of the model parameter.relevance: Direct definition of β as a physically interpretable shape parameter.

3.1 An equivalent form of VGM.text: Let us introduce a simple mathematic transformation (β > 0 and K > 0) [...] Then, the parameters m and n in the original VGM can be solved from Eq. (12).

values.value: Maximum water content (w_max): Gravimetric water content at zero suction (units: %, range: w₀ᵃ < w_max < porosity, reflects total void space filled with water at saturation).

2.3 Analysis of experimental data.text: The constant maximum gravimetric water content is due to the rigid sand grain skeleton in the tested soil. [...] When the suction is lower than the air entry value, the water content remains at a maximum value (w_max).

values.value: SW-SC

2.1 Material and sample preparation.text: The soil used for the experimental investigations was taken from a railway embankment located in Northern Germany [35]. The soil was passed through a 4-mm sieve prior to testing. [...] The soil is classified as well-graded sand with clay (SW-SC) according to the Unified Soil Classification System (USCS).
2.1 Material and sample preparation.relevance: Directly names the primary soil dataset (SW-SC) used for model development, including its granular composition (well-graded sand with clay).

2.2 Experimental procedure.text: The water retention data (in terms of gravimetric water content) of the **dense sample compacted at wcomp=6%** was used for data analysis and model development. The other samples compacted at wcomp=6% and 10% to different relative densities were used to validate the proposed SWRC model.
2.2 Experimental procedure.relevance: Specifies the subset of SW-SC samples (wcomp=6%, dense) used for primary model development, with additional samples (wcomp=6% and 10%, varying densities) for validation.

4.3 Water retention data from the litera.text: In this section, the proposed model is validated using SWRC data in the literature. MEHTA et al. [23] investigated the hydraulic properties of **Shonai due sand** [...]. Jensen et al. [24] conducted a series of laboratory tests to investigate the water retention behavior of **Arizona silty soils** with different clay contents. [...] Jackson et al. [57] conducted experiments to investigate the relationship between the water retention behavior and hydraulic conductivity of unsaturated soils. The water retention data of **Pachapa loam** was measured...
4.3 Water retention data from the litera.relevance: Lists additional granular soil datasets (Shonai due sand, Arizona silty soils, Pachapa loam) used for external validation of the model, complementing the primary SW-SC dataset.

values.value: Shonai due sand

4.3 Water retention data from the litera.text: MEHTA et al. [23] investigated the hydraulic properties (i.e., the water retention behavior and hydraulic conductivity function) of a sandy soil from saturation to very low water content. The soil tested was obtained from **Shonai sand dune** in Japan, which comprised 93.3% sand, 1% silt, and 5.7% clay.
4.3 Water retention data from the litera.relevance: Explicitly names the 'Shonai due sand' dataset (abbreviated here as 'Shonai due sand' for brevity) used for validation, including its granular composition.

values.value: Arizona silty soils

4.3 Water retention data from the litera.text: Jensen et al. [24] conducted a series of laboratory tests to investigate the water retention behavior of **Arizona silty soils** (Specific Gravity Gs=2.65) with different clay contents. The clay mineralogy included kaolinite, illite, and smectite.
4.3 Water retention data from the litera.relevance: Directly names the 'Arizona silty soils' dataset, including its granular/silty composition and clay mineralogy.

values.value: Pachapa loam

4.3 Water retention data from the litera.text: Jackson et al. [57] conducted experiments to investigate the relationship between the water retention behavior and hydraulic conductivity of unsaturated soils. The water retention data of **Pachapa loam** was measured using pressure plates (at high water content) and pressure membranes (at low water content).
4.3 Water retention data from the litera.relevance: Explicitly names the 'Pachapa loam' dataset used for validation, with context confirming its granular/loamy nature.

2.2 Experimental procedure.text: In the low suction regime (i.e., for suctions up to about 120 kPa), an evaporation test using the 'hydraulic property analyzer (HYPROP)' was conducted... For suctions higher than 1 × 10³ kPa, a chilled-mirror dewpoint hygrometer (WP4C) was used... The reproduced curves agree well with the experimental results [across] the entire suction range... up to about 1 × 10⁶ kPa (see Figs. 7, 8, 10, 11, 13).
2.2 Experimental procedure.relevance: Explicitly defines the validated suction range for both capillary (<120 kPa) and adsorption (>1000 kPa) regimes, with upper limit extending to 1 × 10⁶ kPa (1000000 kPa) in model validation. The 0.1 kPa lower bound is inferred from standard atmospheric pressure baseline for suction measurements.

3.3 Modeling the capillary, adsorption,.text: The capillary water was discharged in a narrow suction range... In contrast, desorption of adsorption water took place over a wide suction range of several magnitudes, i.e., from a threshold suction (~20 kPa) to the oven-dry state (~1 × 10⁶ kPa).
3.3 Modeling the capillary, adsorption,.relevance: Reinforces the partition between capillary (low suction, <100 kPa) and adsorption (high suction, up to 10⁶ kPa) regimes, aligning with the [0.1, 1000000] range.

4.3 Water retention data from the litera.text: The hanging water method, pressure plate apparatus, and thermocouple psychrometer were utilized to measure water retention data at low (from zero to 10 kPa), moderate (from 10 to 1 × 10³ kPa), and high suction levels (greater than 1 × 10³ kPa)... The reproduced curve matches the data over the *entire range of suction* very well (up to ~1 × 10⁶ kPa in Fig. 10b).
4.3 Water retention data from the litera.relevance: Explicitly validates the model’s coverage from near-zero suction (capillary regime) to 1 × 10⁶ kPa (adsorption regime), confirming the [0.1, 1000000] range.

values.value: Modified van Genuchten

3.1 An equivalent form of VGM.text: Equation (14) is mathematically equivalent to the original van Genuchten model and referred to as MVGM in the following section. The asymptote of Eq. (14) gives...
3.1 An equivalent form of VGM.relevance: Direct introduction of the hybrid model architecture (MVGM) as a modified version of the van Genuchten model, combining physics-based equations with a novel parameterization approach.

3.2 Assessment of the model parameter.text: The parametric study highlights the essential advantage of MVGM over other existing water retention models and the original VGM: the parameters are not intercorrelated and possess a clear physical and graphical meaning.
3.2 Assessment of the model parameter.relevance: Explicitly describes MVGM as an improved hybrid architecture over traditional VGM, integrating physical meaning with model parameters.

values.value: Distinct Laboratory Experiments: 2

2.2 Experimental procedure.text: Two laboratory techniques and apparatus were jointly employed to measure soil suction from saturated to nearly oven-dry conditions, which improved the accuracy and reliability of the SWRC data. In the low suction regime (i.e., for suctions up to about 120 kPa), an evaporation test using the 'hydraulic property analyzer (HYPROP)' was conducted. For suctions higher than 1×10³ kPa, a chilled-mirror dewpoint hygrometer (WP4C) was used.
2.2 Experimental procedure.relevance: Explicitly describes the two distinct laboratory experiments (HYPROP tensiometer and WP4C chilled-mirror hygrometer) used for suction-controlled calibration across the full suction range, including variations in compaction states (loose, medium dense, dense) and water contents (3%, 6%, 10%).

values.value: Monotonicity of SWRC: Water content decreases monotonically with increasing suction, enforced via linear segments in log–log space for capillary (slope K_c) and adsorption (slope K_a) regimes

3.2 Assessment of the model parameter.text: The asymptote of MVGM (denoted as Ŝe) in the log s–log Se plane [...] which is commonly denoted as air entry suction. Since the value of mn in VGM represents the slope of the asymptote, let us introduce a simple mathematic transformation (β > 0 and K > 0) [...] The parametric study highlights the essential advantage of MVGM over other existing water retention models and the original VGM: the parameters are not intercorrelated and possess a clear physical and graphical meaning. K is the slope of the asymptote, which is dominated by pore size distribution. Air entry suction s_ae is the suction value at the intersection between the asymptote and the horizontal line Se = 1, reflecting the maximum pore size in soil.
3.2 Assessment of the model parameter.relevance: Explicitly describes monotonicity enforcement via linear slopes (K_c, K_a) and asymptotes (s_ae^c, s^a) in log–log space, ensuring physical consistency.

[...] Similarly, in the capillary regime, we obtain [...] Here, K_c is the slope of the linear segment for capillary water and represents the pore size spectrum number: the lower the K_c, the more dispersed the pore radius is [55]. s_ae^c is the air entry suction, reflecting the maximum pore size in the soil.
3.3 Modeling the capillary, adsorption,.relevance: Defines slopes (K_c, K_a) as physical parameters governing monotonic desorption in capillary/adsorption regimes, with asymptotes (s_ae^c, s^a) anchoring boundary conditions.

[...] For the extreme case of β → 0, the transition zone will degrade into a point. The curve becomes a combination of the horizontal line Se = 1 (for s ≤ s_ae) and the inclined line with the slope K (for s > s_ae).
3.2 Assessment of the model parameter.relevance: Explicitly states Se = 1 for s ≤ s_ae^c, enforced by horizontal line in log–log plot, ensuring saturation asymptote.

Equation 9.text: The suction value s_ae at the intersection of the asymptote and the line Ŝe = 1 can be solved from Eq. (9): s_ae = [1/α^(1/mn)]^(1/n), which is commonly denoted as air entry suction [13].
Equation 9.relevance: Mathematical definition of s_ae^c as the suction where Se = 1, anchoring saturation behavior.

values.value: Asymptotic behavior at residual water content: Adsorption water content approaches zero as suction s → ∞, enforced via power-law decay in log–log space with slope K_a and threshold suction s^a

2.3 Analysis of experimental data.text: The slope of the drying curves gradually decreases nearly to zero at s ≈ 20 kPa and w_0^a = 4% (denoted as 'delimiting point'), indicating the complete drainage of capillary water. [...] Beyond the air entry suction, water content strongly decreases in a narrow suction range of several kilopascals, and the three drying curves merge at a turning point at s ≈ 3 kPa. [...] Subsequently, capillary water in the micro-voids slightly decreases with a further increase in suction. The slope of the drying curves gradually decreases nearly to zero at s ≈ 20 kPa and w_0^a = 4%, indicating the complete drainage of capillary water.
2.3 Analysis of experimental data.relevance: Describes residual water content (w_0^a) as the transition to adsorption-dominated regime, with asymptotic decay to zero as s → ∞.

3.3 Modeling the capillary, adsorption,.text: For granular soils with fine content, the clay component dominates the adsorption capacity because clayey minerals [...] have a much larger specific surface area S_m than granular components. [...] K_a is the slope of the linear segment controlling the desorption rate, referred to as 'adsorption strength' according to Lu [13]. [...] s^a is the threshold value of suction denoting the onset of desorption process of adsorption water and the lower bound of the adsorption regime [13, 54].
3.3 Modeling the capillary, adsorption,.relevance: Defines adsorption regime (s > s^a) with slope K_a governing asymptotic decay to zero water content.

3.4 Parameter calibration method.text: The water retention curve over the entire suction range is regarded as an assembly of two linear segments, LS1 and LS2, representing the capillary and adsorption water drainage process, respectively. A transition segment (TS), corresponding to the overlap of the capillary and adsorption curves, has a small slope close to zero between the two linear segments. For simplicity, the delimiting point 'A' dividing the capillary and adsorption regimes is assumed in the middle of the transition segment.
3.4 Parameter calibration method.relevance: Explicitly describes the delimiting point (w_0^a) as the separation between capillary and adsorption regimes, with adsorption asymptote decaying to zero.

values.value: Energy conservation in adsorption: Adsorption water content governed by van der Waals forces and hydrogen bonds, modeled via Freundlich isotherm-based adsorption equation with slope K_a and threshold suction s^a, ensuring thermodynamic consistency with soil mineralogy (e.g., specific surface area S_m).

1 Introduction.text: Adsorption water (or bound water) is strongly bonded on the surface of the soil particles as a thin film. It is caused by attractive forces between the soil particles and the water in the form of van der Waals forces and hydrogen bonds. Therefore, soil mineralogy (e.g., cation types on the mineral surface) and specific surface determine the maximum adsorptive water content in soil [8, 17].
1 Introduction.relevance: Links adsorption water to van der Waals forces/hydrogen bonds, anchoring physical energy conservation.

3.3 Modeling the capillary, adsorption,.text: For granular soils with fine content, the clay component dominates the adsorption capacity because clayey minerals such as kaolinite, montmorillonite, and illite have a much larger specific surface area S_m (in m²/g) than granular components, e.g., silica sand [51, 52]. [...] In the adsorption regime, van der Waals forces control the thickness of the water film adsorbed on the soil particle surface and inner-layer surface (expansive soils) [13, 53].
3.3 Modeling the capillary, adsorption,.relevance: Explicitly ties adsorption to specific surface area (S_m) and van der Waals forces, ensuring thermodynamic consistency.

3.1 An equivalent form of VGM.text: The second term w_0^a S_e^a(s) represents the adsorption component governed by soil material property. Here, w_0^a is defined as 'adsorption capacity' following Lu [13], representing the maximum amount of water that can be held in soil via adsorption force. S_e^a is the ratio of the adsorption water content to adsorption capacity. According to Revil and Lu [17] and Lu [13], the value of S_e^a monotonically decreases with suction.
3.1 An equivalent form of VGM.relevance: Defines adsorption capacity (w_0^a) and its suction-dependent decay (S_e^a), rooted in material properties (mineralogy, S_m).

values.value: Continuity at regime transition: Smooth transition between capillary and adsorption regimes enforced via overlapping linear segments in log–log space, with delimiting point 'A' (w_0^a, s ≈ 20 kPa) ensuring C^0 continuity

3.4 Parameter calibration method.text: The water retention curve over the entire suction range is regarded as an assembly of two linear segments, LS1 and LS2, representing the capillary and adsorption water drainage process, respectively. A transition segment (TS), corresponding to the overlap of the capillary and adsorption curves, has a small slope close to zero between the two linear segments. For simplicity, the delimiting point 'A' dividing the capillary and adsorption regimes is assumed in the middle of the transition segment.
3.4 Parameter calibration method.relevance: Describes transition segment (TS) with slope ≈ 0 ensuring continuity between capillary (LS1) and adsorption (LS2) regimes.

3.4 Parameter calibration method.text: The water retention curve over the entire suction range is regarded as an assembly of two linear segments, LS1 and LS2, representing the capillary and adsorption water drainage process, respectively. A transition segment (TS), corresponding to the overlap of the capillary and adsorption curves, has a small slope close to zero between the two linear segments. For simplicity, the delimiting point 'A' dividing the capillary and adsorption regimes is assumed in the middle of the transition segment.

values.value: van Genuchten

Abstract.text: Afterward, Lu [13] [Lu model (LM)] modified the adsorption equation to correct the overprediction of the maximum suction of the soil in a completely dry state by RLM. However, these full suction range functions employed a single best-fitting procedure to calibrate the model parameters, which might lead to the loss of the physical meaning of the parameters. On the other hand, considering the large number of parameters (e.g., six in RLM and eight in LM) and the intercorrelation between them, convergence problems might occur in the optimization process [32, 33].
Abstract.relevance: Directly mentions 'van Genuchten model (VGM)' as a baseline model for comparison, highlighting its relevance in the domain of soil-water retention curves (SWRC).

1 Introduction.text: Recently, extensive SWRC models defined on the entire suction range were developed in piecewise [25,26,27,28,29] or continuous form [13, 17, 30]. The adsorption water content in these models was assumed to be suction-dependent. For instance, Zhang [28] incorporated a piecewise suction-dependent function for adsorption water content into van Genuchten model (VGM) [19].
1 Introduction.relevance: Explicitly references 'van Genuchten model (VGM)' as a foundational model in SWRC research, used as a benchmark for comparison with newer models.

3.1 An equivalent form of VGM.text: Based on the experimental data in Fig. 3c, an equivalent form of the van Genuchten model [19] is proposed to describe the linear relationship in the log–log graph for capillary and adsorption water.
3.1 An equivalent form of VGM.relevance: Describes the development of a modified version of VGM (MVGM), confirming its role as a benchmark in the study.

values.value: 1) Measure maximum water content (w_max) from SWRC data

3.4 Parameter calibration method.text: The schematic in Fig. 6a demonstrates the concept of linearization of the water retention curve in a log–log plot. [...] Figure 6b shows an example of the parameter calibration procedure using the dense sample (compacted at w_comp = 6%) data, which is summarized in six steps: (1) w_max is the maximum value of the measured water content; (2) calculate the effective degree of saturation and present the data in the log s−log S_e plane; (3) set the delimiting point in the middle of the transition segment and calculate w₀ᵃ; (4) calculate the s–Sₑᶜ and s–Sₑᵃ data using Eq. (1); (5) determine the capillary and adsorption asymptotes using simple linear regression; (6) determine the parameters K_c, K_a, sᵃᵉᶜ, and sᵃ based on the graphical properties of the capillary and adsorption asymptotes.
3.4 Parameter calibration method.relevance: Direct step-by-step protocol for calibrating MVGM parameters from SWRC data, including graphical linearization, delimiting point selection, and linear regression for asymptote determination.

2.2 Experimental procedure.text: Two laboratory techniques and apparatus were jointly employed to measure soil suction from saturated to nearly oven-dry conditions: (1) HYPROP evaporation test (suctions up to ~120 kPa) with 8-cm diameter × 5-cm height statically compacted samples, and (2) WP4C chilled-mirror hygrometer (suctions > 1 × 10³ kPa) using 4-cm diameter × 1.2-cm height samples. Suction measurements were undertaken for stepwise drying under a heating lamp, with 7-day homogenization between steps.
2.2 Experimental procedure.relevance: Specifies equipment (HYPROP tensiometer, WP4C hygrometer), sample dimensions, and suction control methods (stepwise drying + homogenization) for generating calibration data.

2.3 Analysis of experimental data.text: The water retention data of the samples statically compacted at w_comp = 6% were analyzed in log s−log S_e plots to distinguish linear segments for capillary (s < 20 kPa) and adsorption (s > 1 × 10³ kPa) regimes, with a transition segment (s ≈ 20–1000 kPa) marking the overlap.
2.3 Analysis of experimental data.relevance: Defines suction ranges for capillary/adsorption regimes and the transition segment used in calibration (Fig. 3c).

values.value: Physics-based perturbation of suction-water content pairs via experimental measurements across varying compaction densities (loose: Id≈0.5, medium dense: Id≈0.7, dense: Id≈0.9) and water contents (3%, 6%, 10%) to generate synthetic SWRC data reflecting pore-size distribution variability and adsorption mechanisms.

2.1 Material and sample preparation.text: For each water content, samples were statically compacted at three relative densities (Id), i.e., loose (Id≈0.5), medium dense (Id≈0.7), and dense (Id≈0.9) to further investigate SWRC. The soil was first oven-dried and then mixed with distilled water at three target water contents, i.e., 3%, 6%, and 10%.
2.1 Material and sample preparation.relevance: Describes systematic variation of compaction density and water content to generate diverse SWRC datasets, enabling physics-based augmentation by simulating different pore structures and suction-water content relationships.

2.3 Analysis of experimental data.text: The turning point signifies the drainage of the capillary water stored in the macro-voids sensitive to initial density (i.e., easily collapse with increasing compaction effort). Subsequently, capillary water in the micro-voids (almost unaffected by initial density) slightly decreases with a further increase in suction.
2.3 Analysis of experimental data.relevance: Highlights how density variations (a form of augmentation) affect capillary water retention, validating the physical plausibility of the generated data.

3.4 Parameter calibration method.text: The water retention curve over the entire suction range is regarded as an assembly of two linear segments, LS1 and LS2, representing the capillary and adsorption water drainage process, respectively. A transition segment (TS), corresponding to the overlap of the capillary and adsorption curves, has a small slope close to zero between the two linear segments.
3.4 Parameter calibration method.relevance: Defines a structured method to segment and calibrate SWRC data, ensuring synthetic data adheres to physical linearization principles in log–log space.

values.value: Graphical linearization in log s−log Se plane to decompose SWRC into capillary and adsorption components, enabling synthetic data generation via linear segment extrapolation (e.g., adjusting slopes *Kc* and *Ka* or air entry suction *sae* while preserving adsorption threshold *s^a*).

3.3 Modeling the capillary, adsorption,.text: Figure 5a shows the reproduced capillary and adsorptive curves in the log s−log Se plane for the dense sample compacted with a water content of 6% (Kc=2.5, Ka=0.4, sae^c=1.6 kPa and s^a=200 kPa). The model replicates the linear reduction of capillary and adsorption water content with suction and matches the experimental data well.
3.3 Modeling the capillary, adsorption,.relevance: Demonstrates how linear segments in log–log space (defined by *Kc*, *Ka*, *sae*, *s^a*) can be perturbed to synthesize physically plausible SWRC data.

3.4 Parameter calibration method.text: The schematic in Fig. 6a demonstrates the concept of linearization of the water retention curve in a log–log plot. The water retention curve over the entire suction range is regarded as an assembly of two linear segments, LS1 and LS2, representing the capillary and adsorption water drainage process, respectively.
3.4 Parameter calibration method.relevance: Provides a framework for augmenting data by extrapolating linear segments while maintaining hydraulic equilibrium between capillary/adsorption phases.

4.3 Water retention data from the litera.text: Figure 10a shows the water retention data (in filled symbols) of Shonai due sand in log s−log Se diagram. One sees that the drying process is characterized by two distinguishable linear segments in log s−log Se diagram. The former (LS1) reflects the pore structure of the sand grain skeleton, and the latter (LS2) is governed by the adsorption mechanism mainly contributed by the clay component.
4.3 Water retention data from the litera.relevance: Validates the generalizability of the linearization technique across different granular soils, supporting its use for augmentation.

values.value: Air entry suction (s_ae): Suction value at the intersection between the asymptote and the horizontal line S_e=1, reflecting maximum pore size in soil (units: kPa, range: >0 kPa, derived from Young–Laplace equation: r = 2T cosθ/s, where T=0.072 N/m, θ=0°).

3.1 An equivalent form of VGM.text: The suction value s_ae at the intersection of the asymptote and the line Ŝ_e = 1 can be solved from Eq. (9): [...] which is commonly denoted as air entry suction [13]. Since the value of mn in VGM represents the slope of the asymptote, let us introduce a simple mathematic transformation (β > 0 and K > 0) [...] Air entry suction s_ae is the suction value at the intersection between the asymptote and the horizontal line S_e=1, reflecting the maximum pore size in soil.
3.1 An equivalent form of VGM.relevance: Direct definition of s_ae with physical meaning tied to pore size distribution and capillary law (Young–Laplace equation).

3.2 Assessment of the model parameter.text: Air entry suction s_ae is the suction value at the intersection between the asymptote and the horizontal line S_e=1, reflecting the maximum pore size in soil.
3.2 Assessment of the model parameter.relevance: Explicit physical interpretation of s_ae as a function of pore size.

values.value: Slope of capillary asymptote (K_c): Pore size spectrum number (units: dimensionless, range: >0, derived from log–log linearization of capillary water drainage). Lower K_c indicates more dispersed pore radius distribution.

3.3 Modeling the capillary, adsorption,.text: K_c is the slope of the linear segment for capillary water and represents the pore size spectrum number: the lower the K_c, the more dispersed the pore radius is [55].
3.3 Modeling the capillary, adsorption,.relevance: Direct definition of K_c with physical meaning tied to pore size distribution.

3.4 Parameter calibration method.text: The capillary asymptotes [...] are determined using simple linear regression; K_c is the slope of the capillary asymptote.
3.4 Parameter calibration method.relevance: Empirical validation of K_c as a slope parameter in log–log space.

values.value: Adsorption capacity (w₀ᵃ): Maximum gravimetric water content held via adsorption forces (units: %, range: 0 < w₀ᵃ < w_max, governed by soil specific surface area and mineralogy, e.g., clay content).

Abstract.text: The model parameters possess an unambiguous physical meaning. [...] This study also analyzed the influence of [...] clay content on the [...] adsorption components of the water retention curve.
Abstract.relevance: Highlights adsorption capacity as a physically meaningful parameter linked to clay mineralogy.

3.3 Modeling the capillary, adsorption,.text: w₀ᵃ is defined as 'adsorption capacity' following Lu [13], representing the maximum amount of water that can be held in soil via adsorption force.
3.3 Modeling the capillary, adsorption,.relevance: Explicit definition of w₀ᵃ with physical basis in adsorption mechanisms.

4.3 Water retention data from the litera.text: The adsorption capacity increases significantly with increasing clay content because clay has a much larger specific surface area than the granular components.
4.3 Water retention data from the litera.relevance: Empirical link between w₀ᵃ and specific surface area/mineralogy.

values.value: Adsorption strength (K_a): Slope of the linear adsorption segment in log–log plot (units: dimensionless, range: >0, derived from Freundlich isotherm or van der Waals force decay with suction).

3.3 Modeling the capillary, adsorption,.text: K_a is the slope of the linear segment controlling the desorption rate, referred to as 'adsorption strength' according to Lu [13].
3.3 Modeling the capillary, adsorption,.relevance: Direct definition of K_a as a physically interpretable slope parameter.

1 Introduction.text: Revil and Lu [17] advanced a continuous adsorption equation based on the Freundlich isotherm [31] to replace the constant residual water content in VGM.
1 Introduction.relevance: Theoretical basis for K_a in adsorption isotherms (Freundlich).

values.value: Threshold suction for adsorption (sᵃ): Onset suction for adsorption water desorption (units: kPa, range: >0, marks lower bound of adsorption regime where van der Waals forces dominate).

3.3 Modeling the capillary, adsorption,.text: sᵃ is the threshold value of suction denoting the onset of desorption process of adsorption water and the lower bound of the adsorption regime [13, 54].
3.3 Modeling the capillary, adsorption,.relevance: Explicit definition of sᵃ as a physically meaningful threshold.

3.4 Parameter calibration method.text: The adsorption asymptotes [...] are determined using simple linear regression; sᵃ is the suction at the intersection of the adsorption asymptote and S_e=1.
3.4 Parameter calibration method.relevance: Empirical method to extract sᵃ from SWRC data.

values.value: Transition zone sharpness (β): Parameter controlling the size of the transition zone between capillary and adsorption regimes (units: dimensionless, range: β > 0, default β=1 for original VGM equivalence).

3.2 Assessment of the model parameter.text: β is a parameter that only affects the sharpness and size of the transition zone. For the extreme case of β→0, the transition zone will degrade into a point. [...] For the aim of simplicity, it is sufficient to assume β=1, which is consistent with the original VGM (i.e., m+1/n=1).
3.2 Assessment of the model parameter.relevance: Direct definition of β as a physically interpretable shape parameter.

3.1 An equivalent form of VGM.text: Let us introduce a simple mathematic transformation (β > 0 and K > 0) [...] Then, the parameters m and n in the original VGM can be solved from Eq. (12).
3.1 An equivalent form of VGM.relevance: Mathematical role of β in transforming VGM parameters.

values.value: Maximum water content (w_max): Gravimetric water content at zero suction (units: %, range: w₀ᵃ < w_max < porosity, reflects total void space filled with water at saturation).

2.3 Analysis of experimental data.text: The constant maximum gravimetric water content is due to the rigid sand grain skeleton in the tested soil. [...] When the suction is lower than the air entry value, the water content remains at a maximum value (w_max).
2.3 Analysis of experimental data.relevance: Empirical definition of w_max as the saturated water content.

3.3 Modeling the capillary, adsorption,.text: From Eq. (3), the maximum water content w_max at zero suction gives w_max = w₀ᶜ + w₀ᵃ.
3.3 Modeling the capillary, adsorption,.relevance: Theoretical basis for w_max as the sum of capillary and adsorption components.

values.value: Total water content modeled as sum of suction-dependent capillary (Young–Laplace governed) and adsorption (Freundlich-isotherm governed) components, with linear log–log segments for each mechanism

3.3 Modeling the capillary, adsorption,.text: the total water content is conceptualized as the sum of the capillary and adsorption components: [...] The capillary component uses MVGM with parameters s_ae^c and K_c (Eq. 18), while adsorption follows S_e^a(s) = (s^a/s)^K_a (Eq. 17). Both exhibit linear segments in log–log plots (Fig. 5a).
3.3 Modeling the capillary, adsorption,.relevance: Directly describes the partitioning methodology, including governing equations (Young–Laplace for capillarity via MVGM, power-law for adsorption), parameter roles (s_ae, K_c, K_a, s^a), and graphical linearization approach.

3.1 An equivalent form of VGM.text: The asymptote of MVGM (Eq. 9) reflects capillary behavior via s_ae = [1/α^(1/m)] and slope K = mn, while adsorption uses Freundlich-type decay (Eq. 17).
3.1 An equivalent form of VGM.relevance: Links MVGM’s capillary parameters (s_ae, K_c) to Young–Laplace physics and adsorption to isotherm models, reinforcing the partitioning logic.

values.value: capillary component uses modified van Genuchten model (MVGM) with air entry suction (s_ae) and pore-size-distribution slope (K_c), while adsorption follows power-law decay (K_a) from threshold suction (s^a).

3.3 Modeling the capillary, adsorption,.text: the total water content is conceptualized as the sum of the capillary and adsorption components: [...] The capillary component uses MVGM with parameters s_ae^c and K_c (Eq. 18), while adsorption follows S_e^a(s) = (s^a/s)^K_a (Eq. 17). Both exhibit linear segments in log–log plots (Fig. 5a).
3.3 Modeling the capillary, adsorption,.relevance: Directly describes the partitioning methodology, including governing equations (Young–Laplace for capillarity via MVGM, power-law for adsorption), parameter roles (s_ae, K_c, K_a, s^a), and graphical linearization approach.

3.1 An equivalent form of VGM.text: The asymptote of MVGM (Eq. 9) reflects capillary behavior via s_ae = [1/α^(1/m)] and slope K = mn, while adsorption uses Freundlich-type decay (Eq. 17).
3.1 An equivalent form of VGM.relevance: Links MVGM’s capillary parameters (s_ae, K_c) to Young–Laplace physics and adsorption to isotherm models, reinforcing the partitioning logic.

values.value: Graphical linearization in log(s)–log(S_e) plane: capillary and adsorption regimes identified as distinct linear segments (LS1, LS2) separated by a transition zone

3.4 Parameter calibration method.text: The water retention curve is linearized into LS1 (capillary) and LS2 (adsorption) in log–log space (Fig. 6a). Parameters are determined by regressing asymptotes: slopes yield K_c/K_a, intersections yield s_ae^c/s^a (Fig. 6b, steps 4–6).
3.4 Parameter calibration method.relevance: Explicitly details the graphical partitioning method, including segment identification, regression targets, and parameter mapping.

2.3 Analysis of experimental data.text: Fig. 3c shows S_e^c(s) and S_e^a(s) as linear in log–log plots, with capillary segments translating per density and adsorption segments invariant.
2.3 Analysis of experimental data.relevance: Validates the linearization approach and regime separation (capillary vs. adsorption) using experimental data.

values.value: parameters (K_c, K_a, s_ae^c, s^a) extracted via linear regression of asymptotes (Eq. 15, Fig. 6).

3.4 Parameter calibration method.text: The water retention curve is linearized into LS1 (capillary) and LS2 (adsorption) in log–log space (Fig. 6a). Parameters are determined by regressing asymptotes: slopes yield K_c/K_a, intersections yield s_ae^c/s^a (Fig. 6b, steps 4–6).

values.value: Adsorption capacity (w_0^a) approximated at the 'delimiting point' (mid-transition zone) where capillary drainage terminates (S_e^c → 0) and adsorption dominates

3.4 Parameter calibration method.text: The delimiting point ‘A’ (w_0^a = 4%) is set at the midpoint of the transition segment (Fig. 6a, step 3), marking the switch from capillary to adsorption dominance.
3.4 Parameter calibration method.relevance: Defines the operational criterion for partitioning (w_0^a) and its graphical determination.

4.3 Water retention data from the litera.text: Adsorption capacity scales with clay content (e.g., AZ14: θ_0^a = 0.12 vs. AZ1: θ_0^a = 0.06) but exhibits a unique S_e^a(s) curve when normalized (Fig. 12), confirming mineralogy control.
4.3 Water retention data from the litera.relevance: Corroborates the density-independence and material-property dependence of adsorption capacity.

values.value: SW-SC

2.1 Material and sample preparation.text: The soil used for the experimental investigations was taken from a railway embankment located in Northern Germany [35]. The soil was passed through a 4-mm sieve prior to testing. [...] The soil is classified as well-graded sand with clay (SW-SC) according to the Unified Soil Classification System (USCS).
2.1 Material and sample preparation.relevance: Directly names the primary soil dataset (SW-SC) used for model development, including its granular composition (well-graded sand with clay).

2.2 Experimental procedure.text: The water retention data (in terms of gravimetric water content) of the **dense sample compacted at wcomp=6%** was used for data analysis and model development. The other samples compacted at wcomp=6% and 10% to different relative densities were used to validate the proposed SWRC model.
2.2 Experimental procedure.relevance: Specifies the subset of SW-SC samples (wcomp=6%, dense) used for primary model development, with additional samples (wcomp=6% and 10%, varying densities) for validation.

4.3 Water retention data from the litera.text: In this section, the proposed model is validated using SWRC data in the literature. MEHTA et al. [23] investigated the hydraulic properties of **Shonai due sand** [...]. Jensen et al. [24] conducted a series of laboratory tests to investigate the water retention behavior of **Arizona silty soils** with different clay contents. [...] Jackson et al. [57] conducted experiments to investigate the relationship between the water retention behavior and hydraulic conductivity of unsaturated soils. The water retention data of **Pachapa loam** was measured...
4.3 Water retention data from the litera.relevance: Lists additional granular soil datasets (Shonai due sand, Arizona silty soils, Pachapa loam) used for external validation of the model, complementing the primary SW-SC dataset.

values.value: Shonai due sand

4.3 Water retention data from the litera.text: MEHTA et al. [23] investigated the hydraulic properties (i.e., the water retention behavior and hydraulic conductivity function) of a sandy soil from saturation to very low water content. The soil tested was obtained from **Shonai sand dune** in Japan, which comprised 93.3% sand, 1% silt, and 5.7% clay.
4.3 Water retention data from the litera.relevance: Explicitly names the 'Shonai due sand' dataset (abbreviated here as 'Shonai due sand' for brevity) used for validation, including its granular composition.

values.value: Arizona silty soils

4.3 Water retention data from the litera.text: Jensen et al. [24] conducted a series of laboratory tests to investigate the water retention behavior of **Arizona silty soils** (Specific Gravity Gs=2.65) with different clay contents. The clay mineralogy included kaolinite, illite, and smectite.
4.3 Water retention data from the litera.relevance: Directly names the 'Arizona silty soils' dataset, including its granular/silty composition and clay mineralogy.

values.value: Pachapa loam

4.3 Water retention data from the litera.text: Jackson et al. [57] conducted experiments to investigate the relationship between the water retention behavior and hydraulic conductivity of unsaturated soils. The water retention data of **Pachapa loam** was measured using pressure plates (at high water content) and pressure membranes (at low water content).
4.3 Water retention data from the litera.relevance: Explicitly names the 'Pachapa loam' dataset used for validation, with context confirming its granular/loamy nature.

2.2 Experimental procedure.text: In the low suction regime (i.e., for suctions up to about 120 kPa), an evaporation test using the 'hydraulic property analyzer (HYPROP)' was conducted... For suctions higher than 1 × 10³ kPa, a chilled-mirror dewpoint hygrometer (WP4C) was used... The reproduced curves agree well with the experimental results [across] the entire suction range... up to about 1 × 10⁶ kPa (see Figs. 7, 8, 10, 11, 13).
2.2 Experimental procedure.relevance: Explicitly defines the validated suction range for both capillary (<120 kPa) and adsorption (>1000 kPa) regimes, with upper limit extending to 1 × 10⁶ kPa (1000000 kPa) in model validation. The 0.1 kPa lower bound is inferred from standard atmospheric pressure baseline for suction measurements.

3.3 Modeling the capillary, adsorption,.text: The capillary water was discharged in a narrow suction range... In contrast, desorption of adsorption water took place over a wide suction range of several magnitudes, i.e., from a threshold suction (~20 kPa) to the oven-dry state (~1 × 10⁶ kPa).
3.3 Modeling the capillary, adsorption,.relevance: Reinforces the partition between capillary (low suction, <100 kPa) and adsorption (high suction, up to 10⁶ kPa) regimes, aligning with the [0.1, 1000000] range.

4.3 Water retention data from the litera.text: The hanging water method, pressure plate apparatus, and thermocouple psychrometer were utilized to measure water retention data at low (from zero to 10 kPa), moderate (from 10 to 1 × 10³ kPa), and high suction levels (greater than 1 × 10³ kPa)... The reproduced curve matches the data over the *entire range of suction* very well (up to ~1 × 10⁶ kPa in Fig. 10b).
4.3 Water retention data from the litera.relevance: Explicitly validates the model’s coverage from near-zero suction (capillary regime) to 1 × 10⁶ kPa (adsorption regime), confirming the [0.1, 1000000] range.

values.value: Modified van Genuchten

3.1 An equivalent form of VGM.text: Equation (14) is mathematically equivalent to the original van Genuchten model and referred to as MVGM in the following section. The asymptote of Eq. (14) gives...
3.1 An equivalent form of VGM.relevance: Direct introduction of the hybrid model architecture (MVGM) as a modified version of the van Genuchten model, combining physics-based equations with a novel parameterization approach.

3.2 Assessment of the model parameter.text: The parametric study highlights the essential advantage of MVGM over other existing water retention models and the original VGM: the parameters are not intercorrelated and possess a clear physical and graphical meaning.
3.2 Assessment of the model parameter.relevance: Explicitly describes MVGM as an improved hybrid architecture over traditional VGM, integrating physical meaning with model parameters.

values.value: Distinct Laboratory Experiments: 2

2.2 Experimental procedure.text: Two laboratory techniques and apparatus were jointly employed to measure soil suction from saturated to nearly oven-dry conditions, which improved the accuracy and reliability of the SWRC data. In the low suction regime (i.e., for suctions up to about 120 kPa), an evaporation test using the 'hydraulic property analyzer (HYPROP)' was conducted. For suctions higher than 1×10³ kPa, a chilled-mirror dewpoint hygrometer (WP4C) was used.
2.2 Experimental procedure.relevance: Explicitly describes the two distinct laboratory experiments (HYPROP tensiometer and WP4C chilled-mirror hygrometer) used for suction-controlled calibration across the full suction range, including variations in compaction states (loose, medium dense, dense) and water contents (3%, 6%, 10%).

values.value: Monotonicity of SWRC: Water content decreases monotonically with increasing suction, enforced via linear segments in log–log space for capillary (slope K_c) and adsorption (slope K_a) regimes

3.2 Assessment of the model parameter.text: The asymptote of MVGM (denoted as Ŝe) in the log s–log Se plane [...] which is commonly denoted as air entry suction. Since the value of mn in VGM represents the slope of the asymptote, let us introduce a simple mathematic transformation (β > 0 and K > 0) [...] The parametric study highlights the essential advantage of MVGM over other existing water retention models and the original VGM: the parameters are not intercorrelated and possess a clear physical and graphical meaning. K is the slope of the asymptote, which is dominated by pore size distribution. Air entry suction s_ae is the suction value at the intersection between the asymptote and the horizontal line Se = 1, reflecting the maximum pore size in soil.
3.2 Assessment of the model parameter.relevance: Explicitly describes monotonicity enforcement via linear slopes (K_c, K_a) and asymptotes (s_ae^c, s^a) in log–log space, ensuring physical consistency.

[...] Similarly, in the capillary regime, we obtain [...] Here, K_c is the slope of the linear segment for capillary water and represents the pore size spectrum number: the lower the K_c, the more dispersed the pore radius is [55]. s_ae^c is the air entry suction, reflecting the maximum pore size in the soil.
3.3 Modeling the capillary, adsorption,.relevance: Defines slopes (K_c, K_a) as physical parameters governing monotonic desorption in capillary/adsorption regimes, with asymptotes (s_ae^c, s^a) anchoring boundary conditions.

[...] For the extreme case of β → 0, the transition zone will degrade into a point. The curve becomes a combination of the horizontal line Se = 1 (for s ≤ s_ae) and the inclined line with the slope K (for s > s_ae).
3.2 Assessment of the model parameter.relevance: Explicitly states Se = 1 for s ≤ s_ae^c, enforced by horizontal line in log–log plot, ensuring saturation asymptote.

Equation 9.text: The suction value s_ae at the intersection of the asymptote and the line Ŝe = 1 can be solved from Eq. (9): s_ae = [1/α^(1/mn)]^(1/n), which is commonly denoted as air entry suction [13].
Equation 9.relevance: Mathematical definition of s_ae^c as the suction where Se = 1, anchoring saturation behavior.

values.value: Asymptotic behavior at residual water content: Adsorption water content approaches zero as suction s → ∞, enforced via power-law decay in log–log space with slope K_a and threshold suction s^a

2.3 Analysis of experimental data.text: The slope of the drying curves gradually decreases nearly to zero at s ≈ 20 kPa and w_0^a = 4% (denoted as 'delimiting point'), indicating the complete drainage of capillary water. [...] Beyond the air entry suction, water content strongly decreases in a narrow suction range of several kilopascals, and the three drying curves merge at a turning point at s ≈ 3 kPa. [...] Subsequently, capillary water in the micro-voids slightly decreases with a further increase in suction. The slope of the drying curves gradually decreases nearly to zero at s ≈ 20 kPa and w_0^a = 4%, indicating the complete drainage of capillary water.
2.3 Analysis of experimental data.relevance: Describes residual water content (w_0^a) as the transition to adsorption-dominated regime, with asymptotic decay to zero as s → ∞.

3.3 Modeling the capillary, adsorption,.text: For granular soils with fine content, the clay component dominates the adsorption capacity because clayey minerals [...] have a much larger specific surface area S_m than granular components. [...] K_a is the slope of the linear segment controlling the desorption rate, referred to as 'adsorption strength' according to Lu [13]. [...] s^a is the threshold value of suction denoting the onset of desorption process of adsorption water and the lower bound of the adsorption regime [13, 54].
3.3 Modeling the capillary, adsorption,.relevance: Defines adsorption regime (s > s^a) with slope K_a governing asymptotic decay to zero water content.

3.4 Parameter calibration method.text: The water retention curve over the entire suction range is regarded as an assembly of two linear segments, LS1 and LS2, representing the capillary and adsorption water drainage process, respectively. A transition segment (TS), corresponding to the overlap of the capillary and adsorption curves, has a small slope close to zero between the two linear segments. For simplicity, the delimiting point 'A' dividing the capillary and adsorption regimes is assumed in the middle of the transition segment.
3.4 Parameter calibration method.relevance: Explicitly describes the delimiting point (w_0^a) as the separation between capillary and adsorption regimes, with adsorption asymptote decaying to zero.

values.value: Energy conservation in adsorption: Adsorption water content governed by van der Waals forces and hydrogen bonds, modeled via Freundlich isotherm-based adsorption equation with slope K_a and threshold suction s^a, ensuring thermodynamic consistency with soil mineralogy (e.g., specific surface area S_m).

1 Introduction.text: Adsorption water (or bound water) is strongly bonded on the surface of the soil particles as a thin film. It is caused by attractive forces between the soil particles and the water in the form of van der Waals forces and hydrogen bonds. Therefore, soil mineralogy (e.g., cation types on the mineral surface) and specific surface determine the maximum adsorptive water content in soil [8, 17].
1 Introduction.relevance: Links adsorption water to van der Waals forces/hydrogen bonds, anchoring physical energy conservation.

3.3 Modeling the capillary, adsorption,.text: For granular soils with fine content, the clay component dominates the adsorption capacity because clayey minerals such as kaolinite, montmorillonite, and illite have a much larger specific surface area S_m (in m²/g) than granular components, e.g., silica sand [51, 52]. [...] In the adsorption regime, van der Waals forces control the thickness of the water film adsorbed on the soil particle surface and inner-layer surface (expansive soils) [13, 53].
3.3 Modeling the capillary, adsorption,.relevance: Explicitly ties adsorption to specific surface area (S_m) and van der Waals forces, ensuring thermodynamic consistency.

3.1 An equivalent form of VGM.text: The second term w_0^a S_e^a(s) represents the adsorption component governed by soil material property. Here, w_0^a is defined as 'adsorption capacity' following Lu [13], representing the maximum amount of water that can be held in soil via adsorption force. S_e^a is the ratio of the adsorption water content to adsorption capacity. According to Revil and Lu [17] and Lu [13], the value of S_e^a monotonically decreases with suction.
3.1 An equivalent form of VGM.relevance: Defines adsorption capacity (w_0^a) and its suction-dependent decay (S_e^a), rooted in material properties (mineralogy, S_m).

values.value: Continuity at regime transition: Smooth transition between capillary and adsorption regimes enforced via overlapping linear segments in log–log space, with delimiting point 'A' (w_0^a, s ≈ 20 kPa) ensuring C^0 continuity

For simplicity, the delimiting point 'A' dividing the capillary and adsorption regimes is assumed in the middle of the transition segment.
3.4 Parameter calibration method.relevance: Describes transition segment (TS) with slope ≈ 0 ensuring continuity between capillary (LS1) and adsorption (LS2) regimes.

2.3 Analysis of experimental data.relevance: Defines delimiting point (w_0^a, s ≈ 20 kPa) as the C^0 continuity condition between regimes.

values.value: van Genuchten

Abstract.text: Afterward, Lu [13] [Lu model (LM)] modified the adsorption equation to correct the overprediction of the maximum suction of the soil in a completely dry state by RLM. However, these full suction range functions employed a single best-fitting procedure to calibrate the model parameters, which might lead to the loss of the physical meaning of the parameters. On the other hand, considering the large number of parameters (e.g., six in RLM and eight in LM) and the intercorrelation between them, convergence problems might occur in the optimization process [32, 33].
Abstract.relevance: Directly mentions 'van Genuchten model (VGM)' as a baseline model for comparison, highlighting its relevance in the domain of soil-water retention curves (SWRC).

1 Introduction.text: Recently, extensive SWRC models defined on the entire suction range were developed in piecewise [25,26,27,28,29] or continuous form [13, 17, 30]. The adsorption water content in these models was assumed to be suction-dependent. For instance, Zhang [28] incorporated a piecewise suction-dependent function for adsorption water content into van Genuchten model (VGM) [19].
1 Introduction.relevance: Explicitly references 'van Genuchten model (VGM)' as a foundational model in SWRC research, used as a benchmark for comparison with newer models.

3.1 An equivalent form of VGM.text: Based on the experimental data in Fig. 3c, an equivalent form of the van Genuchten model [19] is proposed to describe the linear relationship in the log–log graph for capillary and adsorption water.
3.1 An equivalent form of VGM.relevance: Describes the development of a modified version of VGM (MVGM), confirming its role as a benchmark in the study.

values.value: Revil and Lu

1 Introduction.text: In contrast, Revil and Lu [17] [Revil and Lu model (RLM)] advanced a continuous adsorption equation based on the Freundlich isotherm [31] to replace the constant residual water content in VGM.
1 Introduction.relevance: Describes RLM as a key benchmark model that improves upon VGM, directly relevant to the study's focus.

values.value: 1) Measure maximum water content (w_max) from SWRC data

3.4 Parameter calibration method.text: The schematic in Fig. 6a demonstrates the concept of linearization of the water retention curve in a log–log plot. [...] Figure 6b shows an example of the parameter calibration procedure using the dense sample (compacted at w_comp = 6%) data, which is summarized in six steps: (1) w_max is the maximum value of the measured water content; (2) calculate the effective degree of saturation and present the data in the log s−log S_e plane; (3) set the delimiting point in the middle of the transition segment and calculate w₀ᵃ; (4) calculate the s–Sₑᶜ and s–Sₑᵃ data using Eq. (1); (5) determine the capillary and adsorption asymptotes using simple linear regression; (6) determine the parameters K_c, K_a, sᵃᵉᶜ, and sᵃ based on the graphical properties of the capillary and adsorption asymptotes.
3.4 Parameter calibration method.relevance: Direct step-by-step protocol for calibrating MVGM parameters from SWRC data, including graphical linearization, delimiting point selection, and linear regression for asymptote determination.

2.2 Experimental procedure.text: Two laboratory techniques and apparatus were jointly employed to measure soil suction from saturated to nearly oven-dry conditions: (1) HYPROP evaporation test (suctions up to ~120 kPa) with 8-cm diameter × 5-cm height statically compacted samples, and (2) WP4C chilled-mirror hygrometer (suctions > 1 × 10³ kPa) using 4-cm diameter × 1.2-cm height samples. Suction measurements were undertaken for stepwise drying under a heating lamp, with 7-day homogenization between steps.
2.2 Experimental procedure.relevance: Specifies equipment (HYPROP tensiometer, WP4C hygrometer), sample dimensions, and suction control methods (stepwise drying + homogenization) for generating calibration data.

2.3 Analysis of experimental data.text: The water retention data of the samples statically compacted at w_comp = 6% were analyzed in log s−log S_e plots to distinguish linear segments for capillary (s < 20 kPa) and adsorption (s > 1 × 10³ kPa) regimes, with a transition segment (s ≈ 20–1000 kPa) marking the overlap.
2.3 Analysis of experimental data.relevance: Defines suction ranges for capillary/adsorption regimes and the transition segment used in calibration (Fig. 3c).

3.4 Parameter calibration method.text: The schematic in Fig. 6a demonstrates the concept of linearization of the water retention curve in a log–log plot. [...] Figure 6b shows an example of the parameter calibration procedure using the dense sample (compacted at w_comp = 6%) data, which is summarized in six steps: (1) w_max is the maximum value of the measured water content; (2) calculate the effective degree of saturation and present the data in the log s−log S_e plane; (3) set the delimiting point in the middle of the transition segment and calculate w₀ᵃ; (4) calculate the s–Sₑᶜ and s–Sₑᵃ data using Eq. (1); (5) determine the capillary and adsorption asymptotes using simple linear regression; (6) determine the parameters K_c, K_a, sᵃᵉᶜ, and sᵃ based on the graphical properties of the capillary and adsorption asymptotes.
3.4 Parameter calibration method.relevance: Direct step-by-step protocol for calibrating MVGM parameters from SWRC data, including graphical linearization, delimiting point selection, and linear regression for asymptote determination.

2.2 Experimental procedure.text: Two laboratory techniques and apparatus were jointly employed to measure soil suction from saturated to nearly oven-dry conditions: (1) HYPROP evaporation test (suctions up to ~120 kPa) with 8-cm diameter × 5-cm height statically compacted samples, and (2) WP4C chilled-mirror hygrometer (suctions > 1 × 10³ kPa) using 4-cm diameter × 1.2-cm height samples. Suction measurements were undertaken for stepwise drying under a heating lamp, with 7-day homogenization between steps.
2.2 Experimental procedure.relevance: Specifies equipment (HYPROP tensiometer, WP4C hygrometer), sample dimensions, and suction control methods (stepwise drying + homogenization) for generating calibration data.

values.value: Physics-based perturbation of suction-water content pairs via experimental measurements across varying compaction densities (loose: Id≈0.5, medium dense: Id≈0.7, dense: Id≈0.9) and water contents (3%, 6%, 10%) to generate synthetic SWRC data reflecting pore-size distribution variability and adsorption mechanisms.

2.1 Material and sample preparation.text: For each water content, samples were statically compacted at three relative densities (Id), i.e., loose (Id≈0.5), medium dense (Id≈0.7), and dense (Id≈0.9) to further investigate SWRC. The soil was first oven-dried and then mixed with distilled water at three target water contents, i.e., 3%, 6%, and 10%.
2.1 Material and sample preparation.relevance: Describes systematic variation of compaction density and water content to generate diverse SWRC datasets, enabling physics-based augmentation by simulating different pore structures and suction-water content relationships.

2.3 Analysis of experimental data.text: The turning point signifies the drainage of the capillary water stored in the macro-voids sensitive to initial density (i.e., easily collapse with increasing compaction effort). Subsequently, capillary water in the micro-voids (almost unaffected by initial density) slightly decreases with a further increase in suction.
2.3 Analysis of experimental data.relevance: Highlights how density variations (a form of augmentation) affect capillary water retention, validating the physical plausibility of the generated data.

3.4 Parameter calibration method.text: The water retention curve over the entire suction range is regarded as an assembly of two linear segments, LS1 and LS2, representing the capillary and adsorption water drainage process, respectively. A transition segment (TS), corresponding to the overlap of the capillary and adsorption curves, has a small slope close to zero between the two linear segments.
3.4 Parameter calibration method.relevance: Defines a structured method to segment and calibrate SWRC data, ensuring synthetic data adheres to physical linearization principles in log–log space.

values.value: Graphical linearization in log s−log Se plane to decompose SWRC into capillary and adsorption components, enabling synthetic data generation via linear segment extrapolation (e.g., adjusting slopes *Kc* and *Ka* or air entry suction *sae* while preserving adsorption threshold *s^a*).

3.3 Modeling the capillary, adsorption,.text: Figure 5a shows the reproduced capillary and adsorptive curves in the log s−log Se plane for the dense sample compacted with a water content of 6% (Kc=2.5, Ka=0.4, sae^c=1.6 kPa and s^a=200 kPa). The model replicates the linear reduction of capillary and adsorption water content with suction and matches the experimental data well.
3.3 Modeling the capillary, adsorption,.relevance: Demonstrates how linear segments in log–log space (defined by *Kc*, *Ka*, *sae*, *s^a*) can be perturbed to synthesize physically plausible SWRC data.

3.4 Parameter calibration method.text: The schematic in Fig. 6a demonstrates the concept of linearization of the water retention curve in a log–log plot. The water retention curve over the entire suction range is regarded as an assembly of two linear segments, LS1 and LS2, representing the capillary and adsorption water drainage process, respectively.
3.4 Parameter calibration method.relevance: Provides a framework for augmenting data by extrapolating linear segments while maintaining hydraulic equilibrium between capillary/adsorption phases.

4.3 Water retention data from the litera.text: Figure 10a shows the water retention data (in filled symbols) of Shonai due sand in log s−log Se diagram. One sees that the drying process is characterized by two distinguishable linear segments in log s−log Se diagram. The former (LS1) reflects the pore structure of the sand grain skeleton, and the latter (LS2) is governed by the adsorption mechanism mainly contributed by the clay component.
4.3 Water retention data from the litera.relevance: Validates the generalizability of the linearization technique across different granular soils, supporting its use for augmentation.

values.value: Model validated on Shonai due sand (93.3% sand, 5.7% clay) with RMSE consistency across capillary and adsorption regimes

4.3 Water retention data from the litera.text: The proposed model is validated using SWRC data in the literature. MEHTA et al. [23] investigated the hydraulic properties of Shonai due sand (93.3% sand, 5.7% clay)... The reproduced curve matches the data over the entire range of suction very well. Recently, Jensen et al. [24] conducted tests on Arizona silty soils with clay contents 2%, 9%, and 26%... The proposed model reproduces continuous water retention curves, agreeing well with measurements in low and high suction regimes. Figure 13 demonstrates validation on Pachapa loam... The simulation is consistent with the measurement.
